issues.title: Composite Attester definition
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Composite Device (CD) and Layered Attester (LA) are basic composition patterns.

If we are introducing a new term, Composite Attester (CA), it may be worth giving it more expressive power than just a handy shorthand for CD _or_ LA.

I suppose we could say that a CA is either a CD, an LA, or any composition involving one or more CDs and/or LAs, and thus have a more useful term in our vocabulary.

As an example of its use, take a CCA system with a separately attested GPU, exposing a [`ratsd`](https://github.com/veraison/ratsd) endpoint as the lead attester.

The resulting CA would be a CD made of one LA (the CCA platform and realm) plus a "singleton" attester (the GPU).

Even fancier compositions can be imagined in systems spanning multiple physical nodes.

issues.title: Is "sub" the right term?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
It says:

> _"[..] sub-Attester to address the sub-entity"_


While I get where this is coming from (i.e., RFC9334's "Composite Device"), we want to be able to cover more than just CDs.  Besides, there is not necessarily a hierarchical relationship in the composition which is suggested by "sub".

I propose using the term "component Attester" instead.

issues.title: wrong use of "in tandem"
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
It says:

> Verifiers need to work in tandem

but "in tandem" means "_two_ working together".

Since we are not putting any limitations on the number of Verifiers that are supposed to cooperate, the term is used incorrectly.

I suggest

> Verifiers need to cooperate

or 

> Verifiers need to work together

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
I asked my lovely tool the meaning of word :

What is in tandem means: Here is the reply:

The phrase "in tandem" means **_two or more things_** happening together, simultaneously, or in coordination.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Unsure who or what the "lovely tool" is you are referring to :-)

Anyway, my English vocabulary talks specifically about "two elements working together".

So, there is at least some potential confusion which can be avoided by using a more simple term, like "together".

issues.title: problematic 1st para of "Multi Verifier topological patterns"
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The following sentence has a number of issues:

> _"A composite Attester as per RATS definition has multiple layers. Each layer requires a different set of Verifiers. Hence multi Verifiers work in tandem to appraise a composite Attester."_

1. There is no "RATS definition" of "composite Attester"
2. Layers exist in layered attester, not in composite devices
3. A single verifier could handle multiple layers by itself
4. The conclusion _"Hence..."_ is predicated on a set of incomplete/wrong/partially true assumptions.
5. Use of "tandem" is incorrect in this context (see also #7)

issues.title: processing of single-signature composite evidence: example of requirement?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
It says:

> In certain topologies, it is possible that only the Composite Evidence is Signed to provide the overall integrity, while the individual sub-Attester Evidence (example Evidence 1) is not protected. In such cases, the Lead Verifer upon processing of Composite Evidence produce an Attestation Result first, stash the sub-Attester Evidence (example Evidence 1) as unprocessed Evidence, sign the AR and send it to its Verifier (example Verifier 1).

It is not clear if the described processing is just an example or if it is expected that verifiers will behave like that.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
There are cases, where Evidences (from different RoT) are individually NOT signed but protected by outer signature.

We need to cater this case also, so just referred to that here.

Changed the Model to wrap individual Evidences in a Signed CMW, instead of in an AR, as it was un-necessary!

issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The content of the section is pretty confusing.

The title suggests I could find the description of the trust relationship among the involved actors (attester, front-end verifier and  back-end verifiers), but it contains a mix of security considerations and AR assembly.

The section should clearly state who needs to trusts who, and to do what, very clearly, maybe even schematically.

Crypto signatures generation and validation, as well as AR assembly and processing are just implementation details.

issues.title: Cascaded pattern description
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
I am unsure about the description of the interaction between verifiers in the cascaded pattern.

One fundamental high level principle that is not discussed is how the chain is constructed.
Another discussion to be had is around exchanged conceptual messages.  RATS require a verifier to consume evidence and produce attestation results.  The "CE & partial AR" combo doesn't fit well in that model.

A few clarifications:

1. Why is it necessary to assume that each verifier knows the entire composite attester topology?
2. Why Is it necessary to assume that the first verifier decodes CE?  (If fact, what does it mean to "decode CE"? Is it _complete_ decoding?)
3. Is it necessary to assume that any verifier can be an equivalent entry point in the verification chain?
4. How is the subsequent verifier identified?
5. Is it possible for two or more verifiers in the chain to have overlapping reference values?  If so, is each doing their separate appraisal?


Note: CAR may be a term of art already: Ned has used it [in a few places](https://github.com/CCC-Attestation/meetings/blob/main/materials/NedSmith_CAR.pdf) to mean Concise Attestation Result.  I suggest picking a different one to avoid confusion.

comments.body: I settled on Aggregated Attestation Results ==> AAR, which is the closest as to what we are doing for collecting the Individual Attestation Results! Modified the draft to reflect this!

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
To your point: 
`One fundamental high level principle that is not discussed is how the chain is constructed.
Another discussion to be had is around exchanged conceptual messages. RATS require a Verifier to consume evidence and produce attestation results. The "CE & partial AR" combo doesn't fit well in that model.`

My 2 cents:
I think, RATS is amply clear that RATS Entities can process Conceptual Messages through Conceptual Message Wrapper.

So the Model assumes that Each Verifier Processes Evidence in a RATS CMW which has a "Partial AR" Attached to it.

It consumes Evidence, then Augments Partial AR and passes the new CMW to the Next Verifier.

The principal Handled message is Evidence ONLY. It just receives Additional MetaData (alongside Evidence) in a CMW, which is propagated down the chain. I think the model is fair enough and does not break RATS principles to the best of our understanding!

comments.body:
> My 2 cents: I think, RATS is amply clear that RATS Entities can process Conceptual Messages through Conceptual Message Wrapper.

No, there is no way CMW can be assumed as a universal RATS wrapper.

If we are assuming a CMW structure, then we must state that explicitly, although I think it's too restrictive.  In fact, EAT/EAR can provide pretty much the same functionality as CMW in this context.  CoEV/CAR too.

[ restoring quoting direction 😄 ]

> > 1. Why is it necessary to assume that each verifier knows the entire composite attester topology?
> 
> The reason been, each of the Individual Verifier receives the Composite Evidence(CE). If in absence of this knowledge, will not be possible to decode the CE.

It doesn't look like a necessity to me.

You can imagine a CMW (or equivalent wrapper) where each evidence entry in the logical collection has a label that maps unambiguously to a specific "attestation scheme" (to use a Veraison term.)

What each node in the Verifiers' chain needs to understand is which label to "de-reference" to obtain the "component Evidence" that it knows how to process.  Once that is done it can replace that label with an equivalent label in the "AR bucket" and attach the corresponding AR.

Such a verifier can be totally blind to all other labels it doesn't know about, i.e., it can completely ignore the global topology and only do its local work.

issues.title: An "Evidence+AR bundle" conceptual message
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
@junzhanghw suggested modelling each verifier in the cascaded verification pattern as the composition of different roles.

```
 i-th stage             i+1-th stage
.----------.            .----------.
|          |            |          |
| Verifier +--|AAR_i|-->|    RP    |
|          |            |          |
+----------+            +----------+
|          |            |          |
| Attester +--|CE_i|--->| Verifier |
|          |            |          |
'----------'            '----------'
```

If we want to split the Evidence+AR bundle into separate RFC9334 conceptual messages while also respecting RFC9334 roles, adjacent cascaded verifiers end up with different assemblies, which is not great.

We could model each cascaded verifier as a three-faced Janus as follows:

```
.----------.
|          |
|    RP    |
|          |
+----------+            .----------.
|          |            |          |
| Verifier +--[AAR_i]-->|    RP    +
|          |            |    |     |
+----------+            +-[AAR_i]--+              
|          |            |    |     |              .----------.
|          |            |    v     |              |          |
| Attester +--[CE_i]--->| Verifier +--[AAR_i+1]-->|   RP     |
|          |            |    |     |              |          | 
'----------'            +-[CE_i+1]-+              +--[....]--+
                        |    |     |              |          |
                        |    v     |              |          |
                        | Attester +--[CE_i+1]--->| Verifier |
                        |          |              |          |
                        '----------'              '--[....]--'
                                                  |          |
                                                  | Attester |
                                                  |          |
                                                  '----------'
```

but this requires new internal interfaces between roles which need to be specified:

1. RP forwards $$AAR_i$$ to the co-located Verifier
2. Verifier manipulates $$CE_i$$ to obtain $$CE_{i+1}$$ which is then forwarded to the co-located Attester.

The RFC9334 aftertaste of this is not good either...

An alternative is to define a new RATS CM, the "Evidence+AR bundle", that is exchanged between adjacent Verifiers.

The Evidence+AR bundle is the composition of two CMs: $$AAR_i$$ and $$CE_i$$.

At each stage, the Evidence+AR bundle evolves as follows:

| stage | $$AAR_i$$ | $$CE_i$$ | 
|---|---|---|
| 1 | $$\emptyset$$ | $$E_1, \ldots, E_n$$ |
| 2 | $$AR_1$$ | $$E_2, \ldots, E_n$$ |
| 3 | $$AR_1, AR_2$$ | $$E_3, \ldots, E_n$$ |
| i-th | $$AR_1, \ldots, AR_{i-1}$$ | $$E_i, \ldots, E_n$$ |
| n | $$AR_1, \ldots, AR_n$$ | $$\emptyset$$ |

When one Evidence is appraised it's removed from the $$CE$$ set and a corresponding Attestation Result is added to the $$AAR$$ set. 

Composite Evidence and composite Attestation Results are just special cases of this new CM, for $$i=1$$ and $$i=n$$, respectively.

>

This "augmented evidence" is a new conceptual message, right?  (We should try to avoid confusion with AR4SI's "AR-augmented evidence," which is a very different thing.)

Do you think it'd materialise in contexts other than cascaded verification?

comments.author: junzhanghw
comments.body:
@thomas-fossati ,

I think in our case, the "augmented evidence" is an extension of the  AR-augmented Evidence in ar4si. I copy some words from ar4si and modify it for the augmented evidence.
When Verifiers trust each other, there is no need to the PoF between Verifiers. What do you think?


   Augmented Evidence:  a bundle of Evidence which includes at least
      the following:

      1.  Verifier signed Attestation Results.  These Attestation
          Results must include Identity (sub) Evidence for the (sub-)Attester, a
          Trustworthiness Vector describing a Verifier's most recent
          appraisal of an (sub-)Attester, and some Verifier Proof-of-Freshness
          (PoF).

       2.  Full or partial information from the original evidence.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> [@thomas-fossati](https://github.com/thomas-fossati) ,
> 
> I think in our case, the "augmented evidence" is an extension of the AR-augmented Evidence in ar4si. I copy some words from ar4si and modify it for the augmented evidence. When Verifiers trust each other, there is no need to the PoF between Verifiers. What do you think?

I don't think this would fly.  The key feature of AR-augmented Evidence is that the Evidence and AR blocs in it are statements about the same "component Attester", whereas in our case the two blocs are _complementary_ statements about the same "composite Attester".

comments.author: junzhanghw
comments.body:
@thomas-fossati ,

In our case, the "Evidence+AR bundle" concept has extended the concept of the list of evidence.

In the original form (of evidence list/evidence of composite device), it is like [ $EV_1$, $EV_2$, ..., $EV_n$, sig($EV_1$, $EV_2$, ..., $EV_n$), PoF]

in the cascade model (or more general ones), it is like
[ $AR_1$, $AR_2$, ..., $EV_k$, ..., $EV_n$, (optional?) sig($AR_1$, $AR_2$, ..., $EV_n$), (optional?) PoF].

the mapping from $EV_i$ to $AR_i$ can be regarded as kind of translation such that the raw data in $EV_i$ can be recognized by the latter entity that needs to proceed it. 

I like your RP/Verifier/Attester 3-body graph. Maybe we can introduce one more body to pre-process the "Evidence+AR bundle", so that RP, Verifier, Attester can still remain their original functions as specified by RFC9334?

```suggestion

```suggestion
A Verifier needs Reference Values and Endorsements from the supply chain actors (for example OEM/ODM) to conduct the appraisal of an Attester. Given the range of Component Attesters in a Composite Attester, it is possible that a single Verifier may not have all the capabilities or the information required to conduct the complete appraisal of the Composite Attester. ```
